Weight loss surgery can be helpful for overweight diabetics.
The benefits of weight loss surgery for mildly obese people with type 2 diabetes can last at least five years, according to a new study.
It is too early to say whether moderately overweight people with diabetes live longer after weight-loss surgery than those who get non-surgical treatments.
"Mortality data takes a long time to show something," said Dr Robin Blackstone, an expert in weight-loss surgery who wrote an editorial accompanying the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight loss surgery, or bariatric surgery, uses various methods to reduce the size of the stomach.
They reduce hunger and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Over the years, bariatric surgery has proved effective in treating type 2 diabetes, but most studies have been done in people who are morbidly obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a certain measure of weight in relation to height, is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9.
A BMI of 25 or more indicates that someone is overweight, and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI here: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, researchers from Taiwan's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data they have collected since 2007 in a study comparing two types of obesity surgery - gastric bypass and gastric banding - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were mildly overweight.
The average BMI among those who underwent the procedure fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of the study.
Meanwhile, the BMI remained about the same at 29 for those who received non-surgical diabetes treatments.
Among those who underwent surgery, the diabetes completely subsided in 36% of the cases and partially in 28%.
In the medically treated group, diabetes resolved completely in only one percent and partially in only about two percent.
In addition, results for blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol were "generally better in the 'surgical' group," the authors found.
The researchers also monitored the patients' blood levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects blood sugar levels over time.
HbA1c should be kept below 7 percent, the researchers write.
After the operation, the average HbA1c level dropped from around 9% to around 6%.
The medical therapy group, however, remained stable at about 8 percent.
But this better "glycemic control" -- as reflected in improved hemoglobin A1c levels -- did not reduce mortality in five years, lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and his colleagues found.
The research team also compared average results for the two types of surgery.

At 5 years, the bypass group had lost more weight (18.7 vs. 14.2 kg), achieved greater reductions in BMI (7.4 vs. 5.1), and hemoglobin A1c (3.1% vs. 2.1%), and had more complete resolution of diabetes (46.9% vs. 16.7%).

While the new study does not show a survival advantage for surgery at five years, there are hints from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery leads to a longer life, says Blackstone of the University of Arizona, College of Medicine Phoenix.
In the Swedish study, obese people who had weight-loss surgery were about 29% less likely to die over 15 years compared to a group that tried more conventional methods.
Although the new study didn't show a survival advantage for surgery patients, Blackstone said it was reassuring for people with a BMI under 35 who are interested in the procedure.
"That's the critical point of this study, because it says that this operation in this lower BMI group is lower," without increased risk of death or kidney disease, she said.
Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously as soon as a patient's BMI is between 27 and 30.
"I think we wait too long to get people to take this seriously," she said.
I think that once they have accumulated these genetic changes that have tied their bodies to obesity and diabetes, reversal is really hard."

Why I will be a witness to an execution in Oklahoma
Later today, barring a late legal intervention, I will watch a man be put to death.

The invitation came first in January through his best friend, and although I was shocked, I agreed.
As the day drew nearer, I began to fear.
So why should I do it?
I agreed because I thought it would be a good opportunity to tell the whole story about the death penalty.
It would provide a unique perspective.
It is true that journalists are allowed to watch executions in the US, and as there are often more applications than spaces available, a macabre lottery is held to decide who is chosen.
Oklahoma has reduced the number of media seats from 12 to five.
Whoever is selected will watch it without emotion.
I can't do that.
I will be sitting next to Richard Glossip's closest friend, with whom I have developed my own relationship over the months with phone calls and a two and half hour visit.
I like the guy.
We often laugh a lot when we speak.
Prison authorities say I cannot be both a witness and a journalist, so I will not be allowed to take a notebook and pen to record what I see.
I just have to try to remember all the details.
An Oklahoma journalist accused me on Twitter of abandoning my impartiality.
Here is the lesson.
Tell the prisoner's story the way he wants it and you get access.
I complained to her.
She admitted that she "could have worded it better", but she still thinks what I'm doing is wrong.
Richard Glossip had problem with some of the things I said and wrote.
He does not tell me what to write and I would not do it even if he did.
I told him he can remove me from his list of witnesses at any time.
But he wants an international reporter to be there to write about it.
When he dies, he thinks that the publicity of the anti-death penalty movement will help.
Kim Bellware, a reporter from the Huffington Post, will sit next to me.
If you want to know more about the case, please listen to the series of podcasts I made.
I don't want to go into all the details again.

His actions after the murder of Barry Van Treese would make him guilty of being an accessory to the crime.

I think that his execution is wrong.

Berlin-Tegel prison: Five square meters cell is inhuman
The Federal Constitutional Court has ruled in favour of an ex-prisoner at Tegel jail who was held in a cell that was too small for months.
Prisoners are generally entitled to compensation for the violation of their human dignity if they are accommodated in cells that are too small.
The Federal Constitutional Court has ruled in a decision published on Wednesday.
The aggrieved can hope for money even if they were only stuck in the cramped spaces for a few days, the judges said (Az.: 1 BvR 1127/14).

A former prisoner was successful with his constitutional complaint in Karlsruhe: he was accommodated in a single cell with a floor area of around five square meters in the Berlin-Tegel penal institution between June and November 2009; the toilet was not separated from the living area.
After that the man, who according to his lawyer is now out again, was moved to a larger cell.
His complaint about the inhumane conditions of detention against the country of Berlin failed.
But the constitutional court overturned the ruling of the Berlin District Court and sent the case back for reconsideration.
They see the human dignity of the man violated.
Supreme Court now decides on the amount of compensation
Although only a few days of the period in question would be decisive for compensation in legal terms, there was a claim for compensation, it was said.
Otherwise, "a stunting of the protection of personality rights would be to be feared".
The court of appeal now has to decide on the level of compensation.
The constitutional judges have in the past often strengthened the rights of prisoners.
In April, they awarded damages to a prisoner who was kept naked in a cell.
The multiple occupancy of a cell without a separate toilet is also inhumane, according to a 2011 ruling.
Karlsruhe also confirmed on Wednesday the Berlin Constitutional Court, which had certified a prisoner in a parallel case in November 2009 a degrading accommodation.
The former plaintiff was accommodated in a cell similar to the one in Karlsruhe for 15 to 21 hours a day over a period of three months.
Berlin's prisons have been in the headlines in recent weeks because of a lack of staff.

Angela Merkel and the refugee policy: "We can do it"
The influx of refugees is a huge challenge - the chancellor is determined to accept it.
What is coming to Germany?

According to forecasts by the federal interior ministry, around 800,000 asylum seekers will come to Germany this year. According to Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel (SPD), Germany is even able to accommodate one million refugees.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel (CDU) has shown determination in the face of the unprecedented challenge: "I say again and again: We can do this, and we will do this."
The following overview shows what is in store for Germany.
According to different forecasts, between 350,000 (estimate of the Federal Ministry of Building) and 400,000 (Pestel Institute estimate) homes are needed each year - for the next five years.
That is almost twice as many as are currently being built (250,000 units).

But the dramatic shortage of housing is particularly in the area of affordable rental housing: each year, 60,000 to 80,000 social housing units are released from the rent control, and refugees will also apply for these particularly cheap apartments.
Federal Minister of Building, Barbara Hendricks (SPD), therefore wants to double the funding, from the current 518 million to one billion euros.

That's a lot too little in the view of the Pestel Institute: 80,000 social housing units should be built every year and the federal government should invest 6.4 billion euros annually to achieve that.
Scientists and the federal construction minister agree that there must be more tax breaks for investments in residential construction.
According to the Institute for Employment Research, it can be expected that in the long-term 55% of refugees in Germany can be employed.

However, refugees in Germany are not systematically asked about their qualifications to help them get started, criticizes Claudia Walter, project manager for integration and education in the Bertelsmann Foundation.
But the key to integrating refugees is whether they can find work in Germany.
Work is the key to social contacts, the appreciation of the host society, but also to the self-esteem of immigrants, says migration researcher Dietrich Thränhardt.
In Germany, according to Thränhardt, there has been a political turnaround: from a ban on working for refugees to the recognition of work.

While there used to be a ban on asylum seekers working for up to five years, this was reduced to three months in November 2014, as was the residency obligation, which restricts asylum seekers to live in one place.
In society, the view that refugees should be granted access to the labour market more quickly, has gained a majority - also because of the shortage of skilled workers.
A big hurdle for access to the job market is the lack of German language skills.
So far, there is not sufficient supply of general and vocational language courses.
Studies also show that jobs are most often obtained through personal contacts.
According to Thraenhardt, building networks is therefore the royal road to work integration.

The Berlin school administration has found that only a few refugee parents are giving their children into daycare, estimated ten to 15 percent: "For the uprooted parents it is first of all very important to keep the family together", says Ilja Koschembar, spokesman for youth and family in the Berlin Senate administration.
To convince the family of the benefits of the daycare center, the administration distributes leaflets in different languages.

If the need for preschool teachers increases significantly due to the large number of refugees, the Berlin Senate would try to increase training capacity - for example, by allowing more vocational schools.
In the countries students without German language skills are prepared for lessons in welcome classes.
But they are not always taught by fully qualified teachers, but, as in Berlin, by teachers who only have a qualification in German as a second language.
There is no shortage of them, says Beate Stoffers of the Berlin school administration.
The German Student Union estimates that about 20 percent of refugees in Germany want to study.
In principle, no federal state prohibits asylum seekers or tolerated from studying - the only exception so far was Berlin, Interior Minister Frank Henkel (CDU) has now abandoned his attitude.
Students who wish to flee could be made easier access to higher education.
Because refugees with a residence permit or tolerance no longer receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act when they start a study.
They are generally not entitled to BAföG because they are not part of the circle of persons entitled to BAföG.
So far tolerated refugees had to live in Germany for four years to be eligible for Bafög, from January 1, 2016, this range is reduced to 15 months.
But this funding gap must also be closed, says Steffen Krach, Berlin's secretary of state for science, and the German Student Union.
Students should get Bafög immediately.
Islam will play a more important role in the future because many refugees are Muslims, and for many of them religion is an important part of their identity.
The state should gradually grant Islam the same rights as the churches and develop the existing state-church relationship into a new state-religion relationship.

EU to double mercury limit in predatory fish
The European Commission wants to double the limits for mercury in large predatory fish and thus expose consumers to a significantly higher dose of the nerve poison.

Consumer organisation Foodwatch, which has a copy of the EU's paper, criticised the proposals: "The risks and side-effects of misguided industrial and environmental policy are being passed on in full to pregnant women and small children," said Matthias Wolfschmidt from Foodwatch.

Wolfschmidt said the limit on the nerve poison mercury in large fish at the top of the food chain, such as sharks and swordfish, should be raised from one to two milligrams of mercury for each kilogram of fish for economic reasons.
But big predatory fish are already so contaminated with mercury that, based on the current limits, about 50 percent of the catches cannot be sold.
After doubling the limits, only 14.5 percent would be unsellable.
In return for this relaxation, the EU wants to tighten the limit for other fish from 0.5 milligrams to 0.1 milligrams of mercury per kilogram, according to Foodwatch.
But Foodwatch said this was a "trick" because smaller freshwater fish such as carp are usually so low in pollutants that they already meet the proposed maximum levels.
The reduction in small fish is therefore "a perfidious diversion that helps only the economy," Wolfschmidt said.
Mercury is a highly toxic heavy metal that accumulates in predatory fish through the food chain.
The German government therefore warns that "even small amounts can cause damage to the nervous system, especially in unborn children."
The Federal Ministry of Environment, however, states on its website, with regard to the applicable maximum values, that "no health risk to the general population" is to be expected.
Mercury gets into the environment mainly through coal burning.

German coal power plants emit more than six tons of mercury per year, according to a written statement from the Federal Environment Ministry to Green Bundestag member Annalena Baerbock, two-thirds of the total amount emitted in Germany.
The concentration of mercury in fish in the Elbe, Rhine and Danube rivers was "permanent and nationwide exceeded," the "Spiegel" had quoted the paper in March.
Last year, EU-wide warnings about mercury in fish were among the most common health risks reported in the EU's Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF).
